awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Bio-electro-photonic Microsystem Interfaces for Small Animals
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal Number: ECCS - 1554367 
Proposal Title: CAREER: Bio-electro-photonic Microsystem Interfaces for Small Animals
PI Name: Bozkurt, Alper Y.   	
Institution: North Carolina State University

Objective:
The investigator proposes a wirelessly powered injectable capsule capable of monitoring bio-potentials and bio-photonic physiological signals including heart rate, respiration rate, oxygen saturation, pulse transit time and core body temperature. The proposed investigation includes a complete system integration and extensive evaluation.
 

Non-technical Abstract: The emerging field of Bionic MicroSystems offers new engineering opportunities to solve real life problems. By fusing biological organisms with synthetic electronic systems, a quantum leap can be enabled in our ever-lasting engineering struggle to mimic relatively more complicated properties of biological machines, such as autonomy, intelligence, and biocomplexity observed across various length scales. This project targets to overcome major technical barrier in the way of such achievement, which is the inefficiency of state-of-art interfaces that would provide real-time information about the state of the biological organism. The proposed microsystem will open a physiological window to improve understanding of the physiology of small animals in their natural environment. The unique interdisciplinary and hands-on nature of this project will help us to reach out to all citizens"women and men, underrepresented minorities, and persons with disabilities"and train them to use bioelectronics, biophotonics, and wearable wireless physiological systems. Further, we will design other modules including presentations, show and tell displays, and design contests. We will also use these to develop a new course and lab modules. We will engage with the public at large by means of our collaboration with local museums. In these activities, we will leverage our successful track record of media coverage by and continuing interaction with prominent national and international media agencies.
Technical Abstract: Our long term goal is to enable microsystem based platforms that would perform various physiological measurements wirelessly in small animals. In doing so, we can respond to the critical need for a novel minimally invasive class of systems for continuous recording of key physiological parameters in natural environments without disturbing natural behavior. To address the challenge of higher power consumption of such systems, we will (a) benefit from the advantages of subcutaneous measurements and (b) design custom front-end circuits that would reduce power consumption through multiple strategies. To enable wireless assessment of multiple physiological parameters in ultra-miniaturized form factors, the microsystems will include state-of-the-art circuit approaches, wireless power and communication systems, and sealed packaging with extruding electrodes. The efficacy of the system will be assessed on a four platform testbed: (a) in silico using a computational model, (b) in vitro using a tissue phantom, (c) ex vivo using animal cadavers, and (d) in vivo using rat models.

por.por_cntn:
This project enabled injectable capsule and wearable sensor system platforms to perform various biopotential and biophotonic measurements wirelessly in small animals. These systems responded to the critical need for a novel minimally invasive class of systems for continuous recording of key physiological parameters in natural environments without disturbing natural behavior or requiring a surgical implantation. These systems had the capability of measuring heart rate, respiratory rate, core body temperature and activity levels. Overall, this project resulted in more than thirty peer reviewed journal and conference publications, book chapters, one best paper award, and two patent applications. 

 

Following are the major intellectual merits stemmed from this project:

  1. *Three different application specific integrated circuits  with analog front ends and digital back end blocks combining electrocardiography, electroencephalography, photoplethysmography, temperature measurement, inductive energy harvesting, frequency modulation based wireless transmission and compressive sensing capabilities. 

  2. *Custom organic optical devices (light emitting diodes and photodiodes) with biomimetic nanostructures to increase optoelectronic light transmission efficiency.

  3. *Various custom biopotential electrodes using conductive medical epoxy, 3D printing copper nanoparticles in low-temperature co-fired ceramic base structures and 3D printing all-conductive, graphene-infused PLA base structures.

  4. *Injectable sensors using these application circuits and custom electrodes as well as commercially available integrated circuits. 

  5. *In vitro and in vivo testing and validation of these injectable systems for subcutaneous assessment of photoplethysmography, accelerometry, and thermometry.

  6. *Wearable harness and collar based behavioral, environmental and physiological sensor systems combined with machine learning methods to study scent detection for search and rescue applications, human-animal bonding for therapeutic applications, characterizing dog puppies? suitability for blind guide work, evaluating guide dog temperament, and interfacing working dogs with unmanned air vehicle.

  7. *A systematic survey of literature for animal-assisted interventions in oncology and the use of sensors to assess these interventions objectively and quantitatively.

 

The broader impact of this project included:

  1. *Training six PhD students (two from minority backgrounds in STEM) who had thesis topics related to novel sensor systems for physiological, behavioral and environmental assessment of small animals. 

  2. *Working with several museums to prepare displays and interaction opportunities with general public and children including Marbles' Kid's Museum, North Carolina Museum of Natural Sciences, Los Angeles based California Science Center, Rijksmuseum Boerhaave at Leiden, The  Netherlands and TransNatural Museum at Amsterdam, The Netherlands. 

  3. *Mentoring NC State Science House's CATALYST team (including more than twenty high school students with disabilities from 20 high schools from across North Carolina) who won a Technical Achievement Award  in Lemelson-MIT InvenTeam competition, received a letter of support from President Obama and visited by NC Governor Roy Cooper. 

  4. *Playing an active technical committee member role in the newly emerging Animal Computer Interaction Conference by Association for Computing Machinery. 

  5. *Supporting NC State Science House through Imhotep Academy and Kyran Anderson Academy to organize several summer camps for more than two hundred students from third to eleventh grades from seven urban and rural counties across the North Carolina with mostly (>60%) African-American ethnic background and with more gender representation of females (>50%). 

  6. *Experiments and publications with non-profits (Guiding Eyes for the Blind (GEB), Duke Lemur Center), industry (IMEC-Belgium, IBM, Murata Japan) and national labs (Oak Ridge). 

  7. *Hosting several TV crews to get mass media and website outlets to cover the research activities including (NBC, ABC, Spectrum News, National Geographic, IBM)

  8. *Research collaboration with IBM being highlighted by "Tweets" from NC Representative David Price and NC Senator Thom Tillis and C-Span covering the Smart Collar System being presented at the Capitol. 

These are some significant highlighted outcomes of this research project where the impact of the presented building blocks of an injectable system for small animals and educational materials reached out to millions of people around the world through various outreach activities and will continue to affect the next generation sensor systems to study animals and their interactions with humans.
